JHU to Invest Only in Sullivan Principle Signers
Hopkins has begun divesting
itself of stocks of companies
which do business in South
Africa and which have not signed
the Sullivan Principles, according to University President
Steven Muller.
Muller said the change has
taken place gradually during
the last several months. Immediately prior to South
African Anglican Bishop Desmond Tutu's visit Jan. 10, the
decision was widely publicized.
The Sullivan Principles are a
voluntary code of business
practices which commit signers
to equal pay for blacks and
whites, access to job training
for blacks and efforts to improve the quality of life for
non-whites.

fines or community service

Colombo said that the
smaller fraternities had complained that the larger ones
knowingly violated the policy,
and were able to absorb the
penalties easily. Therefore, he
said, the new penalties were
instituted.
After rush, when the normal
alcohol 'policy of the

back into effect, Colombo said
violations by fraternities will be
handled on a "case-by-case
basis."

grappling recently with

weaken, and, in some cases, get

Texas, Georgia, Virginia,
College,
Clinch
Valley
Oklahoma, Arizona, Arkansas
and Maryland, among other
campuses, moved to dissolve all
or parts of their campus
governments.
In most cases, reformers
argued the governments were
ineffective or meaningless.
They actually succeeded in
abolishing governments at
Texas and Georgia.
At both those campuses, administrators eventually helped
rebuild student governments.
But now at Texas and some
other campuses, reformers are
at it again.

for their help with the series,
and the Wenner-Gren Foundation for Anthropological
Research, the Maryland
Humanities Council, and the
National Endowment for the
Humanities, which help to support the lectures.
Sturtevant described, and illustrated with many slides, the
development and spread of the
American Indian headdress. He
explained that ethnic symbols
develop when sharp distinctions
between cultures exist. The
headdress arose as a symbol of
ethnic identity at a time when
panindian ethnic sentiment
began to overcome loyalty to individual tribes and features of
dress were becomming important to other American ethnic
groups.
According to Sturtevant, the
development of the modern
plains headdress or "war bonnet," now used as a symbol
both by and for American Indians, involved at least one major process of cultural feedback. When Brazil was
discovered by Europeans in the
early sixteenth century, the
Tupinamba tribe of Indians lived

there. These natives wore a
"feather crown" consisting of
a headdress sypporting a
cylinder of feathers which
flared at the top.
Sturtevant showed many
slides both of these actual
American artifacts and of
European representations of
them.
Originally, a major purpose
of the bonnet was to challenge
enemy warriors to attempt to
take it by killing the wearer.
In Europe, over the next 200
to 250 years, the feather crown,
skirt, and other ornaments
became symbolic of the
American native dress, and
even though various tribes later
contacted in the Americas often
dressed very differently, many
paintings and woodcuts show
them wearing Tupinamba ornaments. Sturtevant explained
that at that time in Europe, the
status of individuals was very
much reflected by their mode of
dress; the words "costume"
and "custom," have a common
root in both English and
French.
The feather crown was introduced to the Indians of
Eastern North America by
Europeans in the seventeenth
and eighteenth centuries, and
these Indians used it as a

cultural boundary marker.
The swept-back war bonnet
of today is thought to have
originated in the Western plains
of the continent. Although
several painters who traveled
among the plains Indians portrayed few of these headdresses,
one Indian drew himself in one,
suggesting that the bonnet was
serving as an ethnic symbol accepted by Indians and others
alike, whether authentically Indian or not.
Twentieth century eastern Indians began to wear the war
bonnet and use it as a "symbol
of Indianness," according to
Sturtevant and shown in several
of his slides. One eastern Indian
had made his headdress from
instructions in the Boy Scout
Handbook—showing that
many Indians knew that the
bonnet was a synthetic smbol,
but intentionally used it
nevertheless.(More recently this
century, it has given way to less
flamboyant symbols such as
thin braids.)
The next lecture in the series
will be given by Professor Franciose Heritier-Auge, the Director of the Laboratoire D'Anthropologie Sociale in Paris, at
8 p.m. on Wednesday,
February 19, in the Garrett
Room of the MSE library.

Why a Protest?
The Hopkins NewsoLetter JHU's
'Whitewash'
A Piece de Resistance
Way back in April of 1984, when
WJHU was first taken off the air to accomodate the renovations of AMR II,
we were all told the station would
return—at 25,000 watts—in about three
months. It's now been 22.
At the time, students didn't have any
particular reason to doubt what University President Steven Muller said in a letter to the Federal Communications Commission: WJHU would return to the air
July 1 or soon thereafter. That was the
last time anyone has been inclined to
believe much of anything the administration has said about the station.
The summer came and went, but when
students returned in the fall, some two
months after the station was to have
returned to the air, nothing had happened. Mid-terms arrived, but the station
still wasn't back. Everybody went home
for Thanksgiving—still with no WJHU.
Finally, in December, about six months
after we had been told the station would
be back, the University announced that
it would indeed return—the following
fall. Now let's remember: this would be
more than a year after the administration had first said the station would come
back on the air.
In any event, B.J. Norris, vice president for communications and public affairs, who had been placed in charge of
the station, began planning for its return.
"Our first priority," she said at the time,
"is to extend our FCC permit," which
was due to expire in February, 1985. To
get an extension required some show of
interest in maintaining a station, and sure
enough the administration suddenly
discovered it could fund a return of the
10-watt station until the power increase.
So that winter the student-run WJHU
went back on the air, while the party-line
was still that the larger station would
start in the fall.
Enter Dave Creagh. Hired during the
summer as WJHU's new General
Manager, he came with a guarantee that
the station would start up in the... no,
not fall—spring. That required another
extension from the FCC, which was by
now said to be less than pleased with
Hopkins. But it granted the extension
anyway, adding that this was the last one
the University would ever get. No pro-

blem, said the administration, the
25,000-watt WJHU will go on the air by
the time the extension expires March 17.
Well... uh... maybe.
Now comes word the new station will
miss the March deadline. Instead, the
newest prediction is that the station will
get its power increase—now lowered to
10,000 watts—in June. Well, we'll
believe it when we see it.
Who is responsible for this mess?
Well, to be frank, we don't know. If the
power increase does come through in
June—a big if—Creagh will have been
on the job for less than a year; he claims
it normally takes 18-24 months to put
together such a station. The simple fact
is we don't know enough about organizing a major radio station to assign the
blame. But we do know enough about
managing a project—any project—to
know that there is blame to be assigned.
The process has simply taken too long.
We tend to believe Creagh's claim that
most of this is not his fault. He is obviously a driven man, one unaccustomed to failure. Instead, we believe the
lion's share of the blame must go to Norris, who dawdled too long in the early
planning stages, and, ultimately, to
University President Steven Muller. As
with the entire university, WJHU is
Muller's responsibility, and he must accept the blame.
But worst of all, it's clear in retrospect
that the administration simply lied
through its teeth. It's obvious that the
people who run Hopkins haven't
distinguished themselves in the WJHU
affair, but surely the University's top officers are not so stupid that they sincerely
estimated a two-year job could be completed in three months.
The administration's reputation is
hardly one of striking efficiency, but
WJHU has become the piece de
resistance of bumbling. The whole thing
has become almost a parody—a bit of
eomic relief from the more serious worries of tuition increases and South
African investments. Perhaps Creagh
can eventually pull the thing together and
create a successful station; we hope so.
But in the meantime, don't hold your
breath for June.

A Fair Date
Following the deliberations on the date
of Spring Fair recently has been about
like watching a tennis match. First the
Fair was set for April 11-13, then it was
moved to May 2-4, and now it is back
on the original April date.
The most interesting thing about the
whole affair, however, is not the date
change, which now seems unavoidable,
but is Associate Dean of Students Chris
Colombo's remarks that the Student
Council does not set the date of the Fair.
The Fair is at least putatively a studentrun event, and almost everyone has tradi-

tionally interpreted that to mean that the
Council sets the date. In fact, the administration has long maintained defacto control over the important aspects of
the Fair, such as the music and beer
policies, but never before has it been
publicly admitted—at least to our
knowledge—that the administration runs
the Fair.
So while the date of the Fair will no
doubt be the issue receiving all the attention in the next few days, a more serious
one—who controls the event—will probably slip away.

A good many novelists lament the day they let their work
slip into the hands of a reputed
film maker, but Manuel Puig is
not one of them. Puig is an experimental realist from Argentina whose latest work, Kiss of
the Spider Woman, continues
the tradition he set with his
earlier novel, The Buenos Aires
Affair. Both are banned in
Argentina because of their
political perspectives and Puig
has wisely chosen to make his
home in New York. Smart
man.
Puig's approach is different
to say the least, but once one
has grown accustomed to his
unusual story-telling style, he
occupies the reader's senses and
is fully absorbing. He likes to
use the debris of the
and
world—newspaper
magazine clippings, police and
hospital reports, shopping
lists—and lets them all tell their
own stories without his comments or intrusions.
Kiss of the Spider Woman, is
actually a running dialogue between two men in a prison cell.
The occupants are Molina and

'Valentin. Molina is a middleaged apolitical homosexual
who is in for eight years for
"corruption of minors." His
unlikely cell mate is Valentin, a
young man who is not particularly sensitive and is highly
involved in the political
resistance movement. He is
held for leading revolutionary
activities and has been tortured
and is further abused as the
work progresses.
The two men are incredibly
different and under other circumstances would not even
acknowledge one another's existence. Within the confines of
a prison cell, with considerable
time to pass, and with the everpresent threat of torture, these
two men who have nothing in
common and nothing to talk
about, pass the time in a
curious way. Molina is a storyteller and he passes the time by
describing movies he has seen.
The movies he retells are real
films and they all touch the
novel's themes of repression
and liberation, beauty and
goodness, love, and fear. The
fascinating twist is that all too
often what occurs in the movies
Molina shares foreshadows a
similar and parallel development in what is happening to
Molina and Valentin (or will).
The movies are entertaining

Puig's approach
is different to say
the least. . .
in themselves and the dialogue
in which they are told is so
natural that the reader occasionally forgets that the story is
about these two men and the
relationship which develops
between them despite their obvious differences, lead astray
into the real world.
A little later on we learn that
Molina has been solicited by the
warden to act as a police plant
in order to extract information
from Valentin regarding the opposition movement. By aiding
the police Molina is promised
an early pardon which would
help his ailing mother recover.
The conflict is clear: Molina
finds himself confronted with a
decision that becomes more and
more unbearable to make as he
and Valentin grow closer in
friendship. At what point you
might ask does a person place
his welfare secondary to his
devotion to another person?
Puig examines this question in
depth in a fascinating, adventurous manner.

Despite the folk-pop hybrid
that dominates the Maniacs'
current album, "The Wishing
Chair," Lombardo says that
the members of the band have
interests that go far beyond the
folk genre.
"At the time [the band formenj
it seemed like we [had a lot of
the same influences]," he

each other for four or five
years, now I know what
everyone really likes."
As for Lombardo, his personal favorites include not only folk acts like Fairport Convention and modern-day
revivalists like Britain's The
Men They Couldn't Hang and
The Boothill Foot-Tappers and
Ireland's The Pogues; he also
enjoys getting down to James
Brown and George Clinton.
The Maniacs' live show
definitely reflects the band
members' varying tastes—they
dabble in reggae, funk, and
straight-ahead rock.
Perhaps influenced by The
Clash, a definite Maniac
favorite, many of their lyrics
are highly political. "We're not
necessarily capital '13
'political
in the sense that we're not
didactic, we don't suggest we
have the answers, we don't suggest solutions," explains Lombardo. "In some ways I think
the most intelligent people are
the ones who don't have
answers, who know how complex these questions really are.
"A lot of our songs are addressing the capitalistic structure, like work is a form of exploitation, and money is the actual force in which your wealth
is more powerful than your
life.. . There are a lot of young
people who don't view their life
in a broader perspective.
They're just concerned with
making their next Volvo payment. I think there's a bit more
to it than that."
Merchant's lyrics are
unusually literate in this day
and age when the words seem
to take a back seat to the beat.
However, the Maniacs actually had to pay for "The Wishing

own budget.
"We were kind of mad,"
says Lombardo. "There are so
many different people who
work for a record company.
Sometimes you'll get the okay
from one person, and then it's
like 'What? What?' when the
boss finds out, and that's exactly what happened. I don't think
[Elektra's their label] the boss
is particularly enthusiastic
about our band, so he was quite
surprised that we had conned
Our way into a lyric sheet."
"I think lyrics are important," he continues, "not just
that our lyrics are meaningful,
Which I think they are, but
because they are kind of difficult to understand without a

in the U.S.A., born in the
U.S.A., born in the U.S.A.'
Okay,I knew you were saying

Lombardo, finished with his
guitar, puts it down on another
-couch. Merchant puts aside her
Walkman, picks it up, and
starts to strum some chords.

produced by Joe Boyd, who
worked with Fairport Convention in the 60s, when legendary
guitarist Richard Thompson
was still in the band. So was the
late Sandy Denny, a vocalist
whom Merchant's singing
sometimes brings to mind. Fairport specialized in redoing

was hard to determine which of
the music was original and
which was traditional. Some of
the Maniacs' songs have that
timeless quality as well, making
Boyd an apt choice.
"He liked us from early on,"

own record label, Hannibal

agent played our tape for Joe

That was fine with the

shortly after Boyd was contracted to do "The Wishing

By RICHARD B. CRAMER

The Academic Council has recommended to
President Gordon that Hopkins admit women
undergraduates for the Fall term of next year.
The Council's recommendations, passed in
its Wednesday meeting, call for Gordon to
appoint a "task force committee" to report
to the Academic Council with full details on
the ,institution of general undergraduate coeducation.
Until this task force completes its work ,it
will not be known how many women will be
admitted and in which classes, or if the total
size of the undergraduate beidy will be changed.
"Some Women"
The Council, however, did specify that
I wanted "some women" to be admitted for
enrollment next year. The statement released
by Dean Kimball's office yesterday said that
it was the Council's intent that Hopkins "proceed as rapidly as feasible to a significant proportion of females in the undergraduate body."
Council members were generally unwilling to
talk about the decision yesterday. The members
of the task force have not been named by
the President. The recommendations of the
Academic Council must be approved by Gordon
end the Board of Trustees before they may be
ected upon. Although Gordon was unavailable
for comment yesterday, it is assumed that he
will react favorably to the recommendations.
The next meeting of the Board of Trustees will
take place on November 10.
The task force will consist of two members
of the faculty, two undergraduates, one rep-

the Freshmen class more than any other.
According to Homewood House sources,President Gordon views the task force as responsible
for reporting on every aspect of the changes
required for coeducation. This indicates that
the committee will look into everything from
alterations in the curriculum to placing
"men" and "women" signs on the doors of
lavatories.
Administrators have been looking into the
problems and possibilities of undergraduate coeducation for some time. Recently, the
Academic Council affirmed undergraduate coeducation "in principle."

"Soon,"Very Soon

Director of Admissions William Brinkley said that
that he would meet. the committee's recommendations "soon" in order to do an effective job of recruiting for the Fall term. "I'm
not ready to move until I get the answers,"
he said. Another administrative source said
that the report of the task force would probably
have to be submitted by November 15 for
coeducation to be successfully implemented
next year.
Brinkley was enthusiastic about the possibilities which coeducation would provide for
Hopkins. He said he wanted to see it become
part of "our total program." He also stated
that it might benefit the recruiting efforts of
the ,University by making Hopkins more attractive to men. Ronald Owens, Assistant Director
of Admissions, said that the coeducation move
would indicate a general improvement in the
social conditions at Hopkins.

No Merger
There had been discussion of the feasibility
of merging with Goucher College instead of
admitting women to Hopkins. It was felt by
some that because Goucher already had all of
the facilities which women require, Hopkins
would be wiser to attempt the merger.
The faculty at Hopkins, however, was largely
against the move. There was a fear that faculty
members here would lose the control which
they exercise over curriculum and program requirements if the university merged with
Goucher. Many faculty members were upset
over the types of courses offered in the
Goucher-Hopkins cooperative program.
In addition, problems of transportation between the two campuses would have proved
difficult to eliminate. Had Hopkins amid Goucher
merged, the university would- have accrued no
financial advantages. Goucher's endowment is
small compared to that of Hopkins.

Albee Plays
This Weekend
by Peter Oehlkers
For the third year in a row,
students here at Hopkins have
had the opportunity to work
under the guidance of one of
the nation's most esteemed
playwrights, Edward Albee. In
early December, Albee picked
a number of potential actors
and directors out of the ranks
of auditioning undergrads and
six student plays out of a pool
of submissions. Intersession
meant a rigorous course of
work with Albee for these
aspiring playwrights, actors,
and directors. Finally, the fruit
of their labor comes to the
stage—this weekend: Friday,
Saturday, and Sunday at 8 p.m.
in the L/V room.
The past two Albee productions have been enjoyable affairs featuring good acting and
always interesting, occasionally brilliant, writing. The coordinator of this program,
Writing Seminars professor
Robert Arellano, hints that this
weekend's shows may be the
best yet. The past two years
have helped smooth out the
workings of the system and
Albee's level of supervision has
been the most productive thus
far.
Two of the chosen plays
come from Arellano's Introductory Playwrighting class,

two come from his Advanced
class, and one comes from his
Intermediate class. One play,
John Lasseigne's Three Voices
was submitted independently.
Lasseigne's play is directed
by John Park. About a murder,
its cast of characters include the
murderer, the victim, and the
victim's son; the play, however,
takes place eight years after the
murder—figure that out. Sandrine Tiller's Like a Fish in the
Water is directed by Jack
Tomalis and is about, simply,
a man, a woman, and some
fish. Herman Ayayo directed
grad student James Boylan's
play, All Soul's Day, which is
about two people that meet in
a church on All Soul's Day.
The remaining three plays are
No Stopping Any Time, by
Duncan Smith, directed by
Anne-Marie Ulrich, and about
two schoolmates who meet
after ten years; A Process ofInspiration, by Herman Ayayo,
directed by Robbie Simon, and
about a novelist who runs dry
and his search for inspiration;
and Jay/Alfred by David
Charles, directed by Rob Grey,
and about two guys and their
attitude(s) toward the opposite
sex.
This weekend's production is
sponsored by the Writing
Seminars department. There
will be no charge for admission.

Finkle's Flawless on Cello
by Jason Hanson

Those in attendance of the
Shriver Hall Concert Series'
most recent offering last Sunday night were treated to a
masterful performance by
cellist David Finkel, winner of
the 1985 New England Conservatory/Piatigorsky Prize. The
prize, won through a competition, is named after the late
cello virtuoso Gregor Piatigorsky and is awarded to the cellist
who excels simultaneously as a
soloist, as a chamber musician,
and as a teacher.
Finkel began his training
with his father at an early age
and has studied under teachers
as distinguished as Msistlav
Rostropovich, present conductor of the National Symphony.
He is currently a member of the
Everson Quartet and is an Artist in Residence of the
Chamber Music Society of the
Lincoln Center.
Pianist Wu Han performed
with Finkel. Han, a graduate of
the Hartt School of Music, is a
skilled accompanist and has
made numerous appearances
with the Emerson String
Quartet.
Sunday's program began
with three classical works: one
each of Beethoven, Schumann,
and Brahms. Standing out
among these was the "Sonata
in Minor for cello and piano,
Op. 83" of Johannes Brahms.
Finkel brought out the
sublime side of the cello with

his reading of the piece. His
playing of the deep, rich
melody of the first section
displayed that its theme,
although written almost entirely
in the lower range of the instrument, can be quite lyrical and
occasionally even romantic.
Finkel's faultless playing of the
many double-stops in the midst
of this section, as well as his
crisp execution of the pizzacato
passages, added vivid color to
the piece. In the second section
of the piece, Finkel starkly contrasted the light and graceful
figures against heavier romantic themes displaying his
multifaceted ability. The intense fugue which began the
third section allowed Finkel to
demonstrate his dexterity, requiring the use of the entire
fingerboard of the instrument
to create polyphonic melodies
from a single instrument.
The second half of the program contained more recent
works including Benjamin Britten's "Sonata in C for Cello
and Piano." The style of this
piece was in complete contrast
to the previous works.
Britten's work begins fairly
simply with a motive, or first
theme, consisting of two scale
steps. Though elementary,
these serve as the subject of
many variations throughout all
four movements of the piece.
To add further interest to the
theme, Britten employs many
of the embellishments available
to stringed instruments such as
pizzacato (plucked) playing,

harmonics, and glissando
(sliding) fingering.
As encore pieces Finkel performed Rachmaninoff's splendid and lyrical "Prelude"
followed by Rostropovich's
"Humeresque," an extremely
complicated piece of deceptive
levity. Both were performed
flawlessly and with utmost attention to the virtues of each.
Throughout the performance,
Finkel displayed his versatility
as an artist and a musician. At
home in most genre, Finkel
is master of not only the printed
music but also of the spirit
within it.
The next concert in the
Shriver Series, on February 15,
features The Beaux Arts Trio.

(CPS)—University of Texas
students are up to their old
anarchic ways again.
Some of them hope to
abolish their student government for the second time in five
years, and there are signs that,
in the process, they may help
feed a reform wave now
washing over student governments nationwide.
Schools as diverse as Notre
Dame, Washington, Swarthmore and Minnesota—among
dozens of others—have been
grappling recently with
measures to restructure,
weaken, and, in some cases, get
rid of their student governments altogether.
It wouldn't be the first time.

Five years ago, reformers at
Texas, Georgia, Virginia,
College,
Clinch
Valley
Oklahoma, Arizona, Arkansas
and Maryland, among other
campuses, moved to dissolve all
or parts of their campus
governments.
In most cases, reformers
argued the governments were
ineffective or meaningless.
They actually succeeded in
abolishing governments at
Texas and Georgia.
At both those campuses, administrators eventually helped
rebuild student governments.
But now at Texas and some
other campuses, reformers are
at it again.

Sturtevant described, and illustrated with many slides, the
development and spread of the
American Indian headdress. He
explained that ethnic symbols
develop when sharp distinctions
between cultures exist. The
headdress arose as a symbol of
ethnic identity at a time when
panindian ethnic sentiment
began to overcome loyalty to individual tribes and features of
dress were becomming important to other American ethnic
groups.
According to Sturtevant, the
development of the modern
plains headdress or "war bonnet," now used as a symbol
both by and for American Indians, involved at least one major process of cultural feedback. When Brazil was
discovered by Europeans in the
early sixteenth century, the
Tupinamba tribe of Indians lived

there. These natives wore a
"feather crown" consisting of
a headdress sypporting a
cylinder of feathers which
flared at the top.
Sturtevant showed many
slides both of these actual
American artifacts and of
European representations of
them.
Originally, a major purpose
of the bonnet was to challenge
enemy warriors to attempt to
take it by killing the wearer.
In Europe, over the next 200
to 250 years, the feather crown,
skirt, and other ornaments
became symbolic of the
American native dress, and
even though various tribes later
contacted in the Americas often
dressed very differently, many
paintings and woodcuts show
them wearing Tupinamba ornaments. Sturtevant explained
that at that time in Europe, the
status of individuals was very
much reflected by their mode of
dress; the words "costume"
and "custom," have a common
root in both English and
French.
The feather crown was introduced to the Indians of
Eastern North America by
Europeans in the seventeenth
and eighteenth centuries, and
these Indians used it as a

cultural boundary marker.
The swept-back war bonnet
of today is thought to have
originated in the Western plains
of the continent. Although
several painters who traveled
among the plains Indians portrayed few of these headdresses,
one Indian drew himself in one,
suggesting that the bonnet was
serving as an ethnic symbol accepted by Indians and others
alike, whether authentically Indian or not.
Twentieth century eastern Indians began to wear the war
bonnet and use it as a "symbol
of Indianness," according to
Sturtevant and shown in several
of his slides. One eastern Indian
had made his headdress from
instructions in the Boy Scout
Handbook—showing that
many Indians knew that the
bonnet was a synthetic smbol,
but intentionally used it
nevertheless.(More recently this
century, it has given way to less
flamboyant symbols such as
thin braids.)

Way back in April of 1984, when
WJHU was first taken off the air to accomodate the renovations of AMR II,
we were all told the station would
return—at 25,000 watts—in about three
months. It's now been 22.
At the time, students didn't have any

July 1 or soon thereafter. That was the
last time anyone has been inclined to
believe much of anything the administration has said about the station.
The summer came and went, but when
students returned in the fall, some two
months after the station was to have
returned to the air, nothing had happened. Mid-terms arrived, but the station
still wasn't back. Everybody went home
for Thanksgiving—still with no WJHU.
Finally, in December, about six months
after we had been told the station would
be back, the University announced that
it would indeed return—the following
fall. Now let's remember: this would be
more than a year after the administration had first said the station would come
back on the air.
In any event, B.J. Norris, vice president for communications and public affairs, who had been placed in charge of
the station, began planning for its return.
"Our first priority," she said at the time,
"is to extend our FCC permit," which
was due to expire in February, 1985. To
get an extension required some show of
interest in maintaining a station, and sure
enough the administration suddenly
discovered it could fund a return of the
10-watt station until the power increase.
So that winter the student-run WJHU
went back on the air, while the party-line
was still that the larger station would
start in the fall.
Enter Dave Creagh. Hired during the
summer as WJHU's new General
Manager, he came with a guarantee that
the station would start up in the... no,
not fall—spring. That required another
extension from the FCC, which was by
now said to be less than pleased with
Hopkins. But it granted the extension
anyway, adding that this was the last one
the University would ever get. No pro-

blem, said the administration, the
25,000-watt WJHU will go on the air by
the time the extension expires March 17.
Well... uh... maybe.
Now comes word the new station will
miss the March deadline. Instead, the
newest prediction is that the station will
get its power increase—now lowered to
10,000 watts—in June. Well, we'll
believe it when we see it.
Who is responsible for this mess?
Well, to be frank, we don't know. If the
power increase does come through in
June—a big if—Creagh will have been
on the job for less than a year; he claims
it normally takes 18-24 months to put
together such a station. The simple fact
is we don't know enough about organizing a major radio station to assign the
blame. But we do know enough about
managing a project—any project—to
know that there is blame to be assigned.
The process has simply taken too long.
We tend to believe Creagh's claim that
most of this is not his fault. He is obviously a driven man, one unaccustomed to failure. Instead, we believe the
lion's share of the blame must go to Norris, who dawdled too long in the early
planning stages, and, ultimately, to
University President Steven Muller. As
with the entire university, WJHU is
Muller's responsibility, and he must accept the blame.
But worst of all, it's clear in retrospect
that the administration simply lied
through its teeth. It's obvious that the
people who run Hopkins haven't
distinguished themselves in the WJHU
affair, but surely the University's top officers are not so stupid that they sincerely
estimated a two-year job could be completed in three months.
The administration's reputation is
hardly one of striking efficiency, but
WJHU has become the piece de
resistance of bumbling. The whole thing
has become almost a parody—a bit of
eomic relief from the more serious worries of tuition increases and South
African investments. Perhaps Creagh
can eventually pull the thing together and
create a successful station; we hope so.
But in the meantime, don't hold your
breath for June.

A Fair Date
Following the deliberations on the date
of Spring Fair recently has been about
like watching a tennis match. First the
Fair was set for April 11-13, then it was
moved to May 2-4, and now it is back
on the original April date.
The most interesting thing about the
whole affair, however, is not the date
change, which now seems unavoidable,
but is Associate Dean of Students Chris
Colombo's remarks that the Student
Council does not set the date of the Fair.
The Fair is at least putatively a studentrun event, and almost everyone has tradi-

tionally interpreted that to mean that the
Council sets the date. In fact, the administration has long maintained defacto control over the important aspects of
the Fair, such as the music and beer
policies, but never before has it been
publicly admitted—at least to our
knowledge—that the administration runs
the Fair.
So while the date of the Fair will no
doubt be the issue receiving all the attention in the next few days, a more serious
one—who controls the event—will probably slip away.

by Gil Israeli
A good many novelists lament the day they let their work
slip into the hands of a reputed
film maker, but Manuel Puig is
not one of them. Puig is an experimental realist from Argentina whose latest work, Kiss of
the Spider Woman, continues
the tradition he set with his
earlier novel, The Buenos Aires
Affair. Both are banned in
Argentina because of their
political perspectives and Puig
has wisely chosen to make his
home in New York. Smart
man.
Puig's approach is different
to say the least, but once one
has grown accustomed to his
unusual story-telling style, he
occupies the reader's senses and
is fully absorbing. He likes to
use the debris of the
and
world—newspaper
magazine clippings, police and
hospital reports, shopping
lists—and lets them all tell their
own stories without his comments or intrusions.
Kiss of the Spider Woman, is
actually a running dialogue between two men in a prison cell.
The occupants are Molina and

'Valentin. Molina is a middleaged apolitical homosexual
who is in for eight years for
"corruption of minors." His
unlikely cell mate is Valentin, a
young man who is not particularly sensitive and is highly
involved in the political
resistance movement. He is
held for leading revolutionary
activities and has been tortured
and is further abused as the
work progresses.
The two men are incredibly
different and under other circumstances would not even
acknowledge one another's existence. Within the confines of
a prison cell, with considerable
time to pass, and with the everpresent threat of torture, these
two men who have nothing in
common and nothing to talk
about, pass the time in a
curious way. Molina is a storyteller and he passes the time by
describing movies he has seen.
The movies he retells are real
films and they all touch the
novel's themes of repression
and liberation, beauty and
goodness, love, and fear. The
fascinating twist is that all too
often what occurs in the movies
Molina shares foreshadows a
similar and parallel development in what is happening to
Molina and Valentin (or will).
The movies are entertaining

Puig's approach
is different to say
the least. . .
in themselves and the dialogue
in which they are told is so
natural that the reader occasionally forgets that the story is
about these two men and the
relationship which develops
between them despite their obvious differences, lead astray
into the real world.
A little later on we learn that
Molina has been solicited by the
warden to act as a police plant
in order to extract information
from Valentin regarding the opposition movement. By aiding
the police Molina is promised
an early pardon which would
help his ailing mother recover.
The conflict is clear: Molina
finds himself confronted with a
decision that becomes more and
more unbearable to make as he
and Valentin grow closer in
friendship. At what point you
might ask does a person place
his welfare secondary to his
devotion to another person?
Puig examines this question in
depth in a fascinating, adventurous manner.

Despite the folk-pop hybrid
that dominates the Maniacs'
current album, "The Wishing

"At the time [the band formenj

As for Lombardo, his personal favorites include not only folk acts like Fairport Convention and modern-day
revivalists like Britain's The
Men They Couldn't Hang and
The Boothill Foot-Tappers and
Ireland's The Pogues; he also
enjoys getting down to James
Brown and George Clinton.
The Maniacs' live show
definitely reflects the band
members' varying tastes—they
dabble in reggae, funk, and
straight-ahead rock.
Perhaps influenced by The
Clash, a definite Maniac
favorite, many of their lyrics
are highly political. "We're not
necessarily capital '13
'political
in the sense that we're not
didactic, we don't suggest we
have the answers, we don't suggest solutions," explains Lombardo. "In some ways I think
the most intelligent people are
the ones who don't have

"A lot of our songs are addressing the capitalistic structure, like work is a form of exploitation, and money is the actual force in which your wealth
is more powerful than your
life.. . There are a lot of young
people who don't view their life
in a broader perspective.
They're just concerned with
making their next Volvo payment. I think there's a bit more
to it than that."
Merchant's lyrics are

However, the Maniacs actually had to pay for "The Wishing

"We were kind of mad,"
says Lombardo. "There are so
many different people who
work for a record company.
Sometimes you'll get the okay

like 'What? What?' when the

similar ideas about music,
similar ideas about how to
work and how to achieve what

gravitate towards the same kind
of people."

By RICHARD B. CRAMER

The Academic Council has recommended to
President Gordon that Hopkins admit women
undergraduates for the Fall term of next year.
The Council's recommendations, passed in
its Wednesday meeting, call for Gordon to
appoint a "task force committee" to report
to the Academic Council with full details on
the ,institution of general undergraduate coeducation.
Until this task force completes its work ,it
will not be known how many women will be
admitted and in which classes, or if the total
size of the undergraduate beidy will be changed.
"Some Women"
The Council, however, did specify that
I wanted "some women" to be admitted for
enrollment next year. The statement released
by Dean Kimball's office yesterday said that
it was the Council's intent that Hopkins "proceed as rapidly as feasible to a significant proportion of females in the undergraduate body."
Council members were generally unwilling to
talk about the decision yesterday. The members
of the task force have not been named by
the President. The recommendations of the
Academic Council must be approved by Gordon
end the Board of Trustees before they may be
ected upon. Although Gordon was unavailable
for comment yesterday, it is assumed that he
will react favorably to the recommendations.
The next meeting of the Board of Trustees will
take place on November 10.
The task force will consist of two members
of the faculty, two undergraduates, one rep-

the Freshmen class more than any other.
According to Homewood House sources,President Gordon views the task force as responsible
for reporting on every aspect of the changes
required for coeducation. This indicates that
the committee will look into everything from
alterations in the curriculum to placing
"men" and "women" signs on the doors of
lavatories.
Administrators have been looking into the
problems and possibilities of undergraduate coeducation for some time. Recently, the
Academic Council affirmed undergraduate coeducation "in principle."

"Soon,"Very Soon

Director of Admissions William Brinkley said that
that he would meet. the committee's recommendations "soon" in order to do an effective job of recruiting for the Fall term. "I'm
not ready to move until I get the answers,"
he said. Another administrative source said
that the report of the task force would probably
have to be submitted by November 15 for
coeducation to be successfully implemented
next year.
Brinkley was enthusiastic about the possibilities which coeducation would provide for
Hopkins. He said he wanted to see it become
part of "our total program." He also stated
that it might benefit the recruiting efforts of
the ,University by making Hopkins more attractive to men. Ronald Owens, Assistant Director
of Admissions, said that the coeducation move
would indicate a general improvement in the
social conditions at Hopkins.

No Merger
There had been discussion of the feasibility
of merging with Goucher College instead of
admitting women to Hopkins. It was felt by
some that because Goucher already had all of
the facilities which women require, Hopkins
would be wiser to attempt the merger.
The faculty at Hopkins, however, was largely
against the move. There was a fear that faculty
members here would lose the control which
they exercise over curriculum and program requirements if the university merged with
Goucher. Many faculty members were upset
over the types of courses offered in the
Goucher-Hopkins cooperative program.
In addition, problems of transportation between the two campuses would have proved
difficult to eliminate. Had Hopkins amid Goucher
merged, the university would- have accrued no
financial advantages. Goucher's endowment is
small compared to that of Hopkins.

get some fine young ladies through transfer,"
he said. No one was willing to speculate on

Albee Plays
This Weekend
by Peter Oehlkers
For the third year in a row,
students here at Hopkins have
had the opportunity to work
under the guidance of one of
the nation's most esteemed
playwrights, Edward Albee. In
early December, Albee picked
a number of potential actors
and directors out of the ranks
of auditioning undergrads and
six student plays out of a pool
of submissions. Intersession
meant a rigorous course of
work with Albee for these
aspiring playwrights, actors,
and directors. Finally, the fruit
of their labor comes to the
stage—this weekend: Friday,
Saturday, and Sunday at 8 p.m.
in the L/V room.
The past two Albee productions have been enjoyable affairs featuring good acting and
always interesting, occasionally brilliant, writing. The coordinator of this program,
Writing Seminars professor
Robert Arellano, hints that this
weekend's shows may be the
best yet. The past two years
have helped smooth out the
workings of the system and
Albee's level of supervision has
been the most productive thus
far.
Two of the chosen plays
come from Arellano's Introductory Playwrighting class,

two come from his Advanced
class, and one comes from his
Intermediate class. One play,
John Lasseigne's Three Voices
was submitted independently.
Lasseigne's play is directed
by John Park. About a murder,
its cast of characters include the
murderer, the victim, and the
victim's son; the play, however,
takes place eight years after the
murder—figure that out. Sandrine Tiller's Like a Fish in the
Water is directed by Jack
Tomalis and is about, simply,
a man, a woman, and some
fish. Herman Ayayo directed
grad student James Boylan's
play, All Soul's Day, which is
about two people that meet in
a church on All Soul's Day.
The remaining three plays are
No Stopping Any Time, by
Duncan Smith, directed by
Anne-Marie Ulrich, and about
two schoolmates who meet
after ten years; A Process ofInspiration, by Herman Ayayo,
directed by Robbie Simon, and
about a novelist who runs dry
and his search for inspiration;
and Jay/Alfred by David
Charles, directed by Rob Grey,
and about two guys and their
attitude(s) toward the opposite
sex.
This weekend's production is
sponsored by the Writing
Seminars department. There
will be no charge for admission.

Finkle's Flawless on Cello
by Jason Hanson

Those in attendance of the
Shriver Hall Concert Series'
most recent offering last Sunday night were treated to a
masterful performance by
cellist David Finkel, winner of
the 1985 New England Conservatory/Piatigorsky Prize. The
prize, won through a competition, is named after the late
cello virtuoso Gregor Piatigorsky and is awarded to the cellist
who excels simultaneously as a
soloist, as a chamber musician,
and as a teacher.
Finkel began his training
with his father at an early age
and has studied under teachers
as distinguished as Msistlav
Rostropovich, present conductor of the National Symphony.
He is currently a member of the
Everson Quartet and is an Artist in Residence of the
Chamber Music Society of the
Lincoln Center.
Pianist Wu Han performed
with Finkel. Han, a graduate of
the Hartt School of Music, is a
skilled accompanist and has
made numerous appearances
with the Emerson String
Quartet.
Sunday's program began
with three classical works: one
each of Beethoven, Schumann,
and Brahms. Standing out
among these was the "Sonata
in Minor for cello and piano,
Op. 83" of Johannes Brahms.
Finkel brought out the
sublime side of the cello with

his reading of the piece. His
playing of the deep, rich
melody of the first section
displayed that its theme,
although written almost entirely
in the lower range of the instrument, can be quite lyrical and
occasionally even romantic.
Finkel's faultless playing of the
many double-stops in the midst
of this section, as well as his
crisp execution of the pizzacato
passages, added vivid color to
the piece. In the second section
of the piece, Finkel starkly contrasted the light and graceful
figures against heavier romantic themes displaying his
multifaceted ability. The intense fugue which began the
third section allowed Finkel to
demonstrate his dexterity, requiring the use of the entire
fingerboard of the instrument
to create polyphonic melodies
from a single instrument.
The second half of the program contained more recent
works including Benjamin Britten's "Sonata in C for Cello
and Piano." The style of this
piece was in complete contrast
to the previous works.
Britten's work begins fairly
simply with a motive, or first
theme, consisting of two scale
steps. Though elementary,
these serve as the subject of
many variations throughout all
four movements of the piece.
To add further interest to the
theme, Britten employs many
of the embellishments available
to stringed instruments such as
pizzacato (plucked) playing,

harmonics, and glissando
(sliding) fingering.
As encore pieces Finkel performed Rachmaninoff's splendid and lyrical "Prelude"
followed by Rostropovich's
"Humeresque," an extremely
complicated piece of deceptive
levity. Both were performed
flawlessly and with utmost attention to the virtues of each.
Throughout the performance,
Finkel displayed his versatility
as an artist and a musician. At
home in most genre, Finkel
is master of not only the printed
music but also of the spirit
within it.
The next concert in the
Shriver Series, on February 15,
features The Beaux Arts Trio.
